channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Drug-addled neo-Nazis. Genocide. American biological weapons factories. The Kremlin has used a barrage of increasingly outlandish falsehoods to justify its invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/UTyISrWvTw

While others have taken up arms, Anastasiya Magerramova uses her phone as a weapon. The press secretary of a hospital in Kyiv, she works with colleagues to document the civilians who stream in. She feels she is fighting for truth in the information war. https://t.co/alMR621X2z
A crucial supply of the world’s fertilizers and grain is trapped in Russia and Ukraine. As prices soar, fears of global hunger are rising. https://t.co/7lGa44WzB1

Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson resembles so many Supreme Court justices nominated before her: a widely admired, Harvard-educated overachiever with a respected record as a federal judge. But she is going where no Black woman has ever gone in American history. https://t.co/X9NQV6wV2T

Dr. Ashish Jha, the dean of Brown University’s School of Public Health, a respected academic and a practicing internist with minimal government experience, is about to join the White House as President Biden’s new coronavirus response coordinator. https://t.co/SWBMR47pmv

The Boeing 737-800 that crashed in the Guangxi region of China on Monday dropped more than 21,000 feet in just over a minute about an hour after takeoff, according to flight data. The plane appeared to briefly regain altitude before continuing to plunge. https://t.co/Lyfm52kQ8y

President Biden will travel to Europe for talks with some of the U.S.’s closest allies this week, in his most direct effort yet to rally opposition to the Russian invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/X4PdLNnUrT

A powerful missile hit a shopping mall in northern Kyiv, reducing what was until recently a hive of commerce into a scene of devastation. Six dead bodies had been pulled from the rubble by early Monday morning.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/YJGpNwtVfb https://t.co/ndqDQc58x0

Breaking News: A Boeing 737 plane operated by China Eastern Airlines crashed in southern China with more than 130 people on board, state media reported.
There was no immediate information on casualties or why the plane went down. https://t.co/wTJ2KTmBdH

The Chinese ambassador to the U.S. said that China would not send weapons to support Russia’s war in Ukraine and that Beijing would “do everything to de-escalate the crisis.” His comments presented a softer tone than the one officials in Beijing have used. https://t.co/xa6y6yHhva

Russia broadened its attack on the Ukrainian city of Mariupol and has forcibly deported thousands of residents, according to city officials.
The battle has become a grim symbol of Russia’s firepower and its frustration in failing to subjugate Ukraine. https://t.co/HNGi0e6o2E

Five years after Myanmar’s military began a killing spree against ethnic Rohingya, the U.S. has concluded that the widespread campaign of rape, crucifixions, and drownings and burnings of families and children amounted to genocide. https://t.co/u747FOmMBn

Breaking News: In a conversation that lasted about two hours, President Biden warned China’s president, Xi Jinping, of “consequences” for Beijing if it helps Russia in Ukraine, said a U.S. official, offering no specifics. https://t.co/6BfHQlc2Sd
Breaking News: Justice Clarence Thomas, the longest-serving member of the Supreme Court, was hospitalized with flulike symptoms, the court said. https://t.co/DBIxhPaBnK

Russia is hemorrhaging outward-looking young professionals. Tens of thousands of young, multilingual urbanites who can work remotely from almost anywhere, many of them in information technology, have made a swift exit. https://t.co/nkKxylPTAk

Ukrainian forces continue to hold off Russian advances near Kyiv, Kharkiv and in large parts of the South. But in the east, Russian forces have made steady progress in recent days, moving west from the separatist-held territory of Donbas. https://t.co/TwWvoBn53r

President Volodymyr Zelensky spoke of parallels in the experiences of the Jewish and Ukrainian peoples in his address to the Israeli Parliament on Sunday. “Our people are now wandering in the world, seeking security,” he said, “as you once did.” https://t.co/avcLMxMkjF
“I had young soldiers talk to me afterward and hug me and cry.” How a general is helping destigmatize mental health issues by speaking openly about his own. https://t.co/iIUYGjSeIN
Drug-addled neo-Nazis. Genocide. American biological weapons factories. The Kremlin has used a barrage of increasingly falsehoods to justify its invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/4MbXVg37Wy

Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III told CBS’s "Face the Nation" that Russia's military campaign in Ukraine has "essentially stalled" after sustaining heavy casualties, characterizing Russian strategy so far as feeding its soldiers "into a wood chipper." https://t.co/98HxxPq0hq

As Russian forces pushed toward Kyiv, they seized an apartment complex in a nearby suburb and held around 200 residents captive. We spoke with seven residents who escaped.
https://t.co/Uqjlda8Ugw https://t.co/E2UWcHML5P

Louise Little shaped the education of her son Malcolm X as he evolved into a powerful thinker and speaker. But for a long time her story rarely figured into accounts of his life — until now. https://t.co/UaW8a1ZT3k
An anti-tank missile sent to Ukraine from Britain is proving adept at destroying Russian tanks in close-quarter ambushes. https://t.co/kyb2z28kg7

Pope Francis on Saturday issued a new constitution to govern the Roman Catholic Church. Among the changes, the 54-page constitution stipulates that baptized lay Catholics, including women, can lead departments traditionally headed by cardinals. https://t.co/PH8u4NKnCi

A police officer in Kenosha, Wis., has resigned from his position as a school security officer after video circulating on social media showed him restraining a 12-year-old student by putting his knee on her neck. https://t.co/DfY7RfUsu9

In Opinion A Gallup poll suggest that "the people who seem to be driving the negative feelings toward American schools do not have children attending them," writes Jessica Grose. https://t.co/Ns4odGsowT

“Russia is heading toward harsher internet censorship akin to China’s Great Firewall to better control its people,” our columnist writes. “The Ukraine crisis has only accelerated a process that started years earlier.”https://t.co/4y1zP4dwnS
In Opinion "Trump and Putin, what a pair, shrinking in stature in the eyes of the world. Tiny, tiny Trump and cruel fool Putin," Maureen Dowd writes. https://t.co/yTFX2uJQJV
Capturing Kyiv, military analysts say, would require a furious and bloody conflict that could be the world’s biggest urban battle in 80 years. https://t.co/yCkdSmVUTa

The first No. 1 seed has fallen: Baylor, the defending champion, was upset by No. 8-seeded North Carolina in overtime.
https://t.co/YSMqq0btso https://t.co/wfzdQUEIdj

A Ukrainian soldier was rescued on Saturday from the debris of a military facility that was destroyed by Russian rockets in Mykolaiv. More than 40 others were killed. The man was buried in the rubble for 30 hours.
https://t.co/B2sJTLkpZu https://t.co/Dvq7vPoVZA

Newly released satellite images show extensive damage to the Mariupol Drama Theater, which was bombed on Wednesday. The word “children” can still be seen in white lettering. Ukrainian officials say hundreds of people could still be trapped inside.
https://t.co/Nd74IWkBqA https://t.co/rajvWwaD66

The desperate race to rescue any survivors entombed for a third night in the ruins of a theater in the besieged city of Mariupol was complicated on Saturday by raging street battles. Russia said on Friday that it was “tightening the noose” around the city. https://t.co/jmGeBuxaUL

Ihor Kalynets, 83, knows something of life under Russia’s thumb. The poet spent nine years in the Soviet Gulag and could only publish abroad for decades.
Today he lives in western Ukraine. As Russia’s invasion continues, he has no intention of leaving. https://t.co/mGJxSjtPrx https://t.co/QKuQc6gIrN

A “killing stone,” which, according to a Japanese myth, is haunted by an evil fox spirit and deadly to humans, has split in two. Now, the stone is prompting theories about what the fracture, and a possible demon on the loose, foretells. https://t.co/y50qCPOA3p

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called publicly on Saturday for direct negotiations with President Vladimir Putin of Russia, but a senior Turkish official said that Mr. Putin was not ready for such talks. https://t.co/E7a4mV4bxk

The war turned ordinary Ukrainians into soldiers and aid workers. The photographer Alexander Chekmenev captured fortitude, desperation and resolve in Kyiv. https://t.co/xsACuJTgA6 https://t.co/fdaKNkkkBF

Three Russian astronauts launched to the International Space Station early Friday wearing yellow and blue flight suits, similar to the colors of Ukraine’s flag. They did not say anything that would suggest that their clothing was a political statement. https://t.co/V9b8JsmfCV

After years of pushing against EU unity and cozying up to Kremlin-friendly firebrands, the leader of Poland’s populist governing party has taken on an unlikely new role: a standard-bearer of European solidarity in defense of Ukraine and democratic values. https://t.co/wVBdJ01dNQ

Ihor Kalynets, 83, knows something of life under Russia’s thumb. The poet spent nine years in the Soviet Gulag and could only publish aboard for decades.
Today he lives in western Ukraine. As Russia’s invasion continues, he has no intention of leaving. https://t.co/M7PmHWkR7j https://t.co/qhtIxlNziy

In Ukraine, the world is watching with horror what is, for Russia, an increasingly standard practice: Its forces conducted similar attacks in Syria, bombing hospitals and other civilian structures as part of an intervention to prop up Syria’s government. https://t.co/AcWyV9HqJM

Russia’s language around its invasion of Ukraine has been dominated by the word “Nazi,” as Vladimir Putin tries to use stereotypes, distorted reality and his country’s lingering World War II trauma to justify the attack. https://t.co/xawacypcTx

In Ukraine, the world is watching with horror what is, for Russia, an increasingly standard practice: Its forces conducted similar attacks in Syria, bombing hospitals and other civilian structures as part of an intervention to prop up Syria’s government. https://t.co/OBhK8t8HnJ

A “killing stone,” which, according to a Japanese myth, is haunted by an evil fox spirit and deadly to humans, has split in two.
Now, the stone is prompting theories about what the fracture, and a possible demon on the loose, foretells. https://t.co/UoMiPyohc9

Alexander Chekmenev, a Ukrainian photographer, has been documenting his country since the 1990s. For @NYTMag, he took portraits of citizens still in Kyiv, revealing fortitude, desperation and resolve in a city under attack. https://t.co/1T2byot0NY

Ukraine’s food supply chain is “falling apart” amid the Russian invasion, and the disruption of food supplies within the country is threatening crucial exports of grain that could undermine global food security, the UN said on Friday. https://t.co/VltencxZnR https://t.co/QY9yEvMQR0

Donald Trump’s presidential campaign has been ordered to pay over $300,000 in legal fees and expenses to an ex-employee who the campaign’s lawyers said violated the terms of a nondisclosure agreement when she accused Trump of forcibly kissing her in 2016. https://t.co/Y3ZEb8dIxk

"Morgue” is seen written on the side of a post office of a Mariupol neighborhood in a video verified by The New York Times. “They store bodies here, which they will have to bury themselves,” a man said in the video. https://t.co/nWuBsncEU2

The U.S. put the world "on notice" Friday not to repair or refuel any of the 100 commercial and private aircraft that had breached export controls by flying into Russia. Violators would face stiff punishment, the Commerce Department said. https://t.co/PeXLqynLBP

North Carolina officials said they plan to investigate whether Mark Meadows, Donald Trump’s chief of staff, broke the law when he registered to vote, and voted, from a remote mobile home where he did not live. https://t.co/v7ODrXhLk8
